questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent headaches over the past 6 months. The patient states that his headaches are worse in the mornings. He also reports several episodes of dizziness and blurry vision. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His only medication is metformin. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Two weeks later, the patient's blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg in both arms. Treatment with losartan is begun. Which of the following is the most likely effect of his new medication?



Urinary sodium excretion
Vessel tone
Renin activity
Angiotensin II level
Aldosterone level



A
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


B
Normal
decreased
normal
normal
normal


C
Increased
decreased
increased
decreased
decreased


D
Increased
decreased
increased
increased
decreased


E
Increased
increased
increased
increased
increased


F
Increased
normal
normal
normal
normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with direct renin inhibitors (e.g., aliskiren). Direct inhibition of renin decreases renin activity, which leads to lower levels of angiotensin II (AT II) and aldosterone. Decreased levels of AT II and aldosterone result in decreased vessel tone and decreased sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, resulting in increased urinary sodium excretion.

The same combination of effects could also be explained by treatment with beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol). Beta-blockers inhibit the production and release of renin, which leads to suppression of the downstream renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) components (i.e., angiotensin II and aldosterone) and, subsequently, mildly decreased vessel tone and increased urinary sodium excretion.

B) INCORRECT:

This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with alpha-1 blockers (e.g., doxazosin), which directly decrease peripheral vessel tone resulting in lower blood pressure. Alpha-1 blockers do not have immediate effects on urinary sodium excretion or the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

C) INCORRECT:

This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril), which inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, resulting in low levels of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II mediates sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, vasoconstriction, and aldosterone release. Hence, decreased activation of angiotensin II receptors would lead to an increase in urinary sodium excretion, decreased vessel tone, and lower levels of aldosterone. The combination of these effects lowers blood pressure. Due to a loss of negative feedback regulation, treatment with ACE inhibitors would typically lead to an increase in renin levels and renin activity.

D) CORRECT:

Angiotensin II receptor antagonists or sartans (e.g., losartan) inhibit angiotensin II AT1 receptors. Angiotensin II mediates sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, vasoconstriction, and aldosterone release. Hence, blocking of angiotensin II receptors leads to increased urinary sodium excretion, decreased vessel tone, and decreased aldosterone levels. The combination of these effects lowers blood pressure. Due to a loss of negative feedback regulation, treatment with sartans typically leads to increased renin levels and increased renin activity, which in turn leads to increased levels of angiotensin II.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

E) INCORRECT:

This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone), which competitively bind to aldosterone receptors in the late distal tubule and the collecting ducts, inhibiting the effects of aldosterone. Inhibition of aldosterone leads to decreased sodium reabsorption resulting in increased urinary sodium excretion. Due to a loss of negative feedback regulation, treatment with aldosterone receptor antagonists leads to an increase in renin activity and downstream renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) components (i.e., angiotensin II) and aldosterone, causing an increase in vessel tone.

F) INCORRECT:

This combination could be explained by early effects of treatment with certain diuretic drugs (e.g., furosemide), which cause increased urinary excretion of electrolytes, such as sodium. On the other hand, prolonged treatment with diuretics can also cause hypovolemia, which would lead to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) resulting in increased renin secretion, angiotensin II and aldosterone levels.
questions.hint: This patient was started on losartan, an angiotensin II receptor antagonist, for the treatment of his arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Eight months ago, she underwent an emergency cardiac catheterization with stenting for myocardial infarction. At the time of discharge, her heart configuration was normal, end-diastolic volume was 300 mL, and ejection fraction was 51%. For the past 8 weeks, she has noticed increasing shortness of breath while playing with her 2-year-old grandson. She feels otherwise well. She has arterial hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. She admits to rarely taking her medication as she usually feels well and has no symptoms. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 142/93 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. ECG shows broad, deep Q waves and T-wave inversion. Echocardiography shows left ventricular thinning and dilation and an end-diastolic volume of 370 mL; ejection fraction is 40%. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's worsening of ventricular function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although inotropic agents such as digoxin improve hemodynamic function in patients with HF, it is mainly used for symptom improvement, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is usually added to baseline treatment with furosemide in patients with HF who do not achieve sufficient diuresis with loop diuretics alone. Thiazides are used for symptom relief, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

C) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine has been found to worsen symptoms and hemodynamic status in patients with HF and reduced ejection fraction. Although recent studies have shown attenuated cardiac remodeling when nifedipine is used, there are alternative drugs that have been established as first-line therapy for cardiac remodeling prevention.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) such as diltiazem have not been found to improve mortality and/or remodeling in patients with HF secondary to myocardial infarction. CCBs are mainly used for symptomatic treatment.

E) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as enalapril have been found to decrease cardiac remodeling by slowing down the rate of left ventricular thinning and dilation after acute MI. This effect is achieved by decreasing preload and afterload due to blockage of angiotensin II. This patient's presentation with dyspnea on exertion, left ventricular dilation on echocardiogram, and worsening ejection fraction of 40% is consistent with mild to moderate HF.

Indications for ACE inhibitors (and angiotensin II receptor antagonists) in the secondary prevention of MI include heart failure, left ventricular ejection fraction < 40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, stable chronic kidney disease, and ST-segment elevation MI (especially with anterior location). Beta blockers have also been shown to have anti-remodeling effects.

F) INCORRECT:

Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa antagonists such as abciximab are mainly used in high-risk patients with myocardial infarction undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Recent studies have shown a decrease in left ventricular remodeling when abciximab is used right after PCI, but these findings were evaluated in a small population and more research is necessary to determine the benefits. There are alternative drugs that have been established as first-line therapy for cardiac remodeling prevention.

G) INCORRECT:

Although statins have been found to play a role in the prevention of left ventricular remodeling in patients with HF after MI, there are alternative drugs that have been established as first-line therapy for cardiac remodeling prevention.
questions.hint: This woman did not adhere to her medication regimen after a myocardial infarction (MI). She now presents with dyspnea on exertion, reduced ejection fraction, and left ventricular thinning and dilation, which is consistent with heart failure (HF), most likely due to unhindered cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: Three days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old woman with resistant hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the doctor because of decreased urination. She denies dysuria, fevers, or chills. Blood pressure is 133/67 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Compared to measurements from one week ago, the glomerular filtration rate is markedly decreased and plasma renin activity is elevated. A duplex ultrasound of the kidneys shows increased systolic flow velocity in both renal arteries when compared to the aorta. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's worsening renal function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the ascending loop of Henle. Although diuresis may decrease the glomerular filtration rate, it does not augment the activity of renin.

B) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone acts on the distal convoluted tubules. It does not directly reduce glomerular filtration rate or increase the activity of renin.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic that acts on the proximal portion of the distal convoluted tubules. Although diuresis may decrease the glomerular filtration rate, it does not increase the activity of renin.

D) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors like enalapril inhibit efferent arteriole constriction, which can lead to a decrease in the GFR and acute kidney injury, as seen here. Patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis are especially susceptible to this effect, as the kidneys rely on efferent arteriole constriction to maintain the GFR. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) work in a similar fashion. Therefore, both ARBs and ACEIs are relatively contraindicated in patients with bilateral renal stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a selective beta blocker that is used to treat hypertension. Beta blockers do not exhibit a marked effect on glomerular filtration rate and should decrease, not increase, renin activity at normal doses.
questions.hint: This patient's duplex ultrasound shows findings consistent with renal artery stenosis, which manifests with increased flow velocity from the narrowed artery.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance. He feels well. His blood pressure is 155/60 mm Hg. Physical exam shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose concentration of 150 mg/dL and a hemoglobin A1c concentration of 9%. Treatment with lisinopril is initiated. Which of the following findings would be expected two days after initiating lisinopril therapy?



Glomerular filtration rate
Renal plasma flow
Filtration fraction



A
↑
no change
↑


B
↓
no change
↓


C
↓
↓
no change


D
↓
↑
↓


E
↓
↓
↑
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These measurements (GFR↑, RPF ↔, FF↑) can be seen in conditions that are associated with a decreased oncotic pressure in the glomerulus (e.g. nephrotic syndrome). A reduction in oncotic pressure causes less fluid to shift back into the capillary system from the glomerulus. Consequently, more fluid is filtered, increasing the glomerular filtration rate and filtration fraction.

B) INCORRECT:

This constellation (GFR↓, RPF ↔, FF↓) can be seen in conditions associated with: decreased coefficient of filtration (e.g., thickened glomerular basement membrane in diabetes mellitus or decreased surface area of glomeruli due to glomerular destruction in necrotizing forms of glomerulonephritis); increased hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's space (e.g. obstructive hydronephrosis); or increased oncotic pressure in the glomerulus (e.g. increased plasma protein concentration in multiple myeloma).

C) INCORRECT:

These changes (GFR↓, RPF↓, FF ↔) can be seen with administration of NSAIDs because they inhibit formation of prostaglandins, which act to preferentially dilate the afferent arteriole. Thus, NSAIDs facilitate afferent arteriolar constriction, increasing resistance to blood flow and ultimately decreasing renal plasma flow. Because the hydrostatic pressure downstream to the afferent arteriole is decreased, the glomerular filtration rate is reduced. These changes are equiproportional, so the filtration fraction is typically not changed.

D) CORRECT:

When initiating treatment with lisinopril, a modest reduction of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is typically seen within the first several days. Simultaneously, renal plasma flow (RPF) is increased and filtration fraction (FF) is decreased. The underlying mechanism is inhibition of angiotensin II synthesis, causing dilation of the efferent arteriole. This increases RPF and reduces GFR due to a decrease in glomerular filtration pressure. Also, the FF is decreased because GFR is decreased and RPF is increased (FF = GFR / RPF).

In patients with a preexisting reduction in RPF (e.g. heart failure), initiation of ACE inhibitors may lead to acute kidney injury.

E) INCORRECT:

These changes (GFR↓, RPF↓, FF↑) can be seen with mild or moderate hypovolemia. Decreased renal plasma flow is the inciting factor owing to renal hypoperfusion.
questions.hint: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, which works by decreasing levels of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II normally constricts the efferent arteriole of the glomerulus.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg on the left arm and 162/90 mm Hg on the right arm. He reports that he is adherent with his medication and exercise regimen. The physician adds a drug to his antihypertensive medication regimen. This drug increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels, and decreases serum aldosterone levels, without affecting bradykinin levels. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Candesartan, which is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), would inhibit the downstream effects of the angiotensin II receptor type 1 (AT1 receptor) such as vasoconstriction and aldosterone release. This leads to lower levels of aldosterone and decreased reabsorption of Na+ and water. To compensate for decreased Na+ and water reabsorption, the juxtaglomerular apparatus will release more renin, which will subsequently increase the levels of both angiotensin I and angiotensin II. Meanwhile, bradykinin levels are not affected, as ARBs have no effect on ACE, which metabolizes bradykinin.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

B) INCORRECT:

Aliskiren, which is a direct renin inhibitor, has no effect on bradykinin levels because it does not affect the activity of ACE. It would also cause a compensatory increase in renin secretion by the juxtaglomerular cells. However, renin inhibition by aliskiren would decrease the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I. Consequently, the levels of angiotensin I and angiotensin II would be decreased rather than increased. Aldosterone levels would be decreased due to decreased angiotensin II levels.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

C) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that lowers blood pressure by various mechanisms, including vasodilation. Vasodilation would stimulate the renin-angiotensin system and increase serum levels of renin, angiotensin I, angiotensin II, and aldosterone, without affecting bradykinin levels. The drug that was administered to this patient decreases aldosterone levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril, which is an ACE inhibitor, blocks the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. It consequently causes a decrease in angiotensin II and aldosterone levels and a compensatory increase in renin and angiotensin I levels increase. As bradykinin undergoes degradation by ACE, lisinopril leads to increased bradykinin levels.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

E) INCORRECT:

Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by inhibiting the sodium channel in the cortical collecting tubule. It does not affect the activity of ACE and therefore has no effect on bradykinin levels. However, natriuresis caused by triamterene would stimulate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Consequently, the levels of renin, angiotensin I, angiotensin II, and aldosterone would all be expected to increase rather than decrease.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

F) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol, which is a β1 receptor antagonist, has no effect on bradykinin levels because it does not affect the activity of ACE but it would block the sympathetic stimulation of β1 receptors on juxtaglomerular cells. Therefore, it would decrease rather than increase renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels. Aldosterone levels would be decreased due to decreased angiotensin II levels.
questions.hint: The drug that was most likely prescribed for this patient is used as an alternative to ACE inhibitors in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors due to bradykinin-induced side effects such as a dry cough.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Her blood pressure is 162/96 mm Hg. Her albumin-to-creatinine ratio is 40 mg/g (N < 30 mg/g). Treatment with enalapril is initiated. Two weeks later, the patient develops a dry cough, and the drug is discontinued. The patient is subsequently started on a new antihypertensive drug. Which of the following is the most likely effect of the new antihypertensive drug?



24-hour urine sodium
Peripheral vascular resistance
Renin
Angiotensin II
Aldosterone



A
Increased
decreased
increased
decreased
decreased


B
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


C
Increased
increased
increased
increased
increased


D
Decreased
decreased
increased
increased
increased


E
Increased
decreased
increased
increased
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril), which inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, resulting in low levels of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II mediates sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, vasoconstriction, and aldosterone release. Decreased activation of angiotensin II receptors would, therefore, lead to an increase in urinary sodium excretion, decreased vessel tone, and lower levels of aldosterone. The combination of these effects lowers blood pressure. Treatment with ACE inhibitors would typically lead to an increase in renin levels and renin activity due to a loss of negative feedback regulation.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

B) INCORRECT:

This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with beta-1 blockers (e.g., metoprolol). Beta-1 blockers inhibit the production and release of renin, which leads to suppression of the downstream renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) components (i.e., angiotensin II and aldosterone) and, subsequently, mildly decreased vessel tone and increased urinary sodium excretion.

C) INCORRECT:

This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with diuretics, which increase urine sodium elimination and cause a transient increase in renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) activity and peripheral vascular tone. Over time, the activity of the RAAS system and peripheral vascular tone will decrease.

D) INCORRECT:

This combination of effects could be explained by treatment with vasodilators such as hydralazine and alpha-1 blockers (e.g., doxazosin), which directly decrease peripheral vessel tone, resulting in lower blood pressure. Increased activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system would occur as a compensatory response to maintain GFR resulting in increased renin, angiotensin II, and aldosterone levels as well as decreased urinary sodium excretion.

E) CORRECT:

Angiotensin II receptor blockers (e.g., losartan, valsartan, candesartan) inhibit angiotensin II receptors (AT1 receptors). Angiotensin II mediates sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, vasoconstriction, and aldosterone release. Blocking of angiotensin II receptors, therefore, leads to an increase in urinary sodium excretion, decreased peripheral vascular resistance, and lower levels of aldosterone. The combination of these effects lowers blood pressure. To compensate for decreased sodium and water reabsorption, the juxtaglomerular apparatus will release more renin, which will subsequently increase the levels of both angiotensin I and angiotensin II. Meanwhile, bradykinin levels are not affected, as ARBs have no effect on ACE, which metabolizes bradykinin. Therefore, ARBs do not cause a dry cough as a side effect.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.
questions.hint: ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) are nephroprotective and typically used as first-line antihypertensive therapy in individuals with hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Individuals who develop adverse effects (e.g., dry cough) of ACE inhibitors are usually started on angiotensin II receptor blockers, as they are also nephroprotective.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and asthma comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of intermittent dry, hacking cough. He does not have fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He does not smoke cigarettes. Current medications include simvastatin, metformin, albuterol, and ramipril. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

choices.text: Start dextromethorphan and increase frequency of albuterol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dextromethorphan is an NMDA glutamate receptor antagonist used as an over-the-counter cough suppressant and albuterol is a beta-2 agonist used in the treatment of asthma. While dextromethorphan might temporarily mitigate this patient's cough, it would not address the root cause of it. Additionally, there is no other evidence that this patient's cough is associated with an asthma exacerbation (such as dyspnea, wheezing, or chest tightness); increasing albuterol is therefore unlikely to resolve this problem.

B) INCORRECT:

Both simvastatin and atorvastatin are statins, which are indicated to treat hyperlipidemia and act by decreasing LDL levels. Classic side effects of statins include myopathy and rhabdomyolysis but not cough. Therefore, changing the patient's medication from simvastatin to atorvastatin would be unlikely to resolve his cough.

C) CORRECT:

Dry cough is a characteristic side effect of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). ACE inhibitors decrease blood pressure by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Inhibition of ACE also causes an increase in bradykinin, which can lead to bronchoconstriction and dry cough. If cough caused by ACE inhibitors is present, discontinuation of ACE inhibitors and switching to angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) such as candesartan is recommended. Cough is a rare adverse effect of ARBs, as these agents do not influence the breakdown of kinins.

Other common adverse effects of ACE inhibitors include hypotension, hyperkalemia, a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and angioedema.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

D) INCORRECT:

Ramipril and lisinopril are both angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). A common side effect of treatment with ACE inhibitors is an intermittent, nonproductive cough, such as the one seen in this patient. Because all ACE inhibitors are known to cause this cough, switching from one agent to another within this class would be unlikely to resolve the problem.

E) INCORRECT:

Albuterol and salmeterol are both beta-2 adrenergic agonists used in the treatment of asthma. While albuterol is a short-acting agent used for acute asthma exacerbations, salmeterol is a long-acting agent used for prophylaxis of asthma attacks. Although this patient has a history of asthma, his current cough seems unrelated to it. He does not have a history or findings to suggest exacerbation of asthma (e.g., exposure to triggers, dyspnea, or tachypnea on examination). Moreover, stopping albuterol would not be appropriate if there was any suspicion of an asthma exacerbation.
questions.hint: Increased local concentrations of bradykinin and substance P are thought to be responsible for the symptom this patient is experiencing.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and systolic heart failure comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath at rest. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, diffuse crackles over the lower lung fields, and bilateral lower extremity edema. As part of the treatment, he is given valsartan in combination with a drug that inhibits neprilysin. This drug has been found to reduce pulmonary capillary wedge pressure and cause systemic hypotension as an adverse effect. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this patient's pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neprilysin degrades angiotensin II, and neprilysin inhibitor therapy increases angiotensin II levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin receptor blockers (e.g., valsartan) inhibit the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and decrease aldosterone levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Neprilysin degrades bradykinin, and neprilysin inhibitor therapy increases bradykinin levels.

D) CORRECT:

Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) is naturally released by ventricular heart muscle cells in response to increased ventricular filling. Patients with heart failure have elevated BNP levels. BNP, which has vasodilatory and diuretic properties, counteracts the effects of neurohormonal overactivation in patients with heart failure (e.g., fluid overload, sodium retention, vasoconstriction). Neprilysin is an endopeptidase that degrades natriuretic peptides (e.g., BNP). Neprilysin inhibitors (e.g., sacubitril) increase the levels of natriuretic peptides. Neprilysin inhibitors also prevent the degradation of angiotensin II and bradykinin. Therefore, angiotensin receptor blockers (e.g., valsartan) are used in combination with neprilysin inhibitors to counteract the effects of angiotensin II. Neprilysin inhibitors should not be used in combination with ACE inhibitors, which also increase bradykinin levels, to avoid an elevated risk of angioedema.

As neprilysin inhibitors can elevate BNP levels, caution should be taken when using BNP levels to assess the severity of heart failure and prognosis in patients taking angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) therapy. NT-proBNP is not degraded by neprilysin and is therefore considered a more dependable marker than BNP in patients undergoing ARNI therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Prostacyclin is a vasodilatory substance, but it is rapidly degraded by nonenzymatic processes rather than by a specific enzyme. Neprilysin inhibitor therapy is therefore unlikely to affect prostacyclin levels. Neprilysin degrades other vasodilatory substances such as substance P.
questions.hint: This patient presents with congestive heart failure (CHF). The drug that was most likely prescribed to this patient is sacubitril. Adverse effects of this medication include hypotension, hyperkalemia, cough, angioedema, and a transient rise in creatinine levels.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man with recently diagnosed nonischemic cardiomyopathy (left ventricular ejection fraction, 30%) presents to clinic. He currently feels well and is able to walk for up to an hour daily without dyspnea or chest discomfort. He reports no orthopnea or edema. His cardiomyopathy was diagnosed during a hospitalization 3 months ago, at which point he started guideline-directed medical therapy. His current medications are carvedilol 12.5 mg twice daily, spironolactone 25 mg daily, dapagliflozin 10 mg daily, sacubitril-valsartan 24/26 mg twice daily, and torsemide 10 mg daily.
He has a BMI of 36, a blood pressure of 112/68 mm Hg, a heart rate of 64 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. His neck circumference is 38.1 cm. Jugular venous pressure is measured at 5 cm of water, the lungs are clear to auscultation, and the heart rate and rhythm are regular without murmurs. The abdomen is soft and nondistended, and the extremities are warm with trace pedal edema bilaterally.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Brain natriuretic peptide (pg/mL)
151
≤38


Sodium (mEq/liter)
140
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.4
3.5–5.0


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.7 (baseline, 1.5)
0.8–1.3


Which one of the following factors is the most likely cause of this patient’s elevated brain natriuretic peptide level?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

BNP and NT-proBNP levels both increase with age, and age-stratified cutoffs are often used. However, this patient is <50 years of age, so a significant age-related increase in BNP levels would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Some studies have shown obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) to be associated with elevated BNP, and heart failure and OSA are common comorbid conditions. More-severe OSA is associated with more-dramatic increases in BNP. Although OSA is possible without a large neck circumference, this patient’s normal neck circumference makes OSA a less likely culprit for his BNP elevation.

C) INCORRECT:

Obesity is not a cause of elevated BNP levels. Studies have shown lower average BNP and NT-proBNP levels in patients with obesity than in those without.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level is most likely secondary to his recent initiation of sacubitril-valsartan, an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) used for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

Heart Failure and ARNI Therapy

The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is central to the pathology of HFrEF. During this disease process, both the RAAS and the sympathetic nervous system (SNS) are activated. Initially, they are adaptive and help to conserve blood pressure and maintain end-organ perfusion. Over time, however, the activation of these systems results in negative cardiac remodeling and deleterious effects. Therefore, the backbone of HFrEF therapy focuses on blunting the activation of the RAAS and SNS systems.

Sacubitril-valsartan is a combination of the angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB) valsartan, which blocks the final step of the RAAS, and the neprilysin inhibitor sacubitril. Neprilysin is an enzyme that degrades beneficial vasoactive peptides (e.g., bradykinin, natriuretic peptides, adrenomedullin). Inhibiting neprilysin allows these protective peptides to counter the neurohormonal overactivation that contributes to negative remodeling, sodium retention, and vasoconstriction. In clinical trials, sacubitril-valsartan has increased the survival benefit seen with angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or ARBs alone in patients with HFrEF. ARNI therapy has also been associated with improvements in left ventricular volumes and left ventricular remodeling. This therapy has therefore become the standard of care to further reduce cardiovascular mortality and heart failure hospitalizations in patients with HFrEF.

Of note, ARNI therapy is associated with a higher frequency and greater severity of hypotension than ACE inhibitors. In addition, modest increases in creatinine should be anticipated with this medication and do not justify discontinuing the drug or titrating the dose.

Effects of ARNI Therapy on BNP Levels

Clinicians should be aware of the effects of ARNI therapy on brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) levels, as these laboratory findings are often used in concordance with symptoms and physical examination findings to establish the existence and severity of heart failure.

Because BNP is normally subject to degradation by neprilysin, BNP levels often rise after the initiation of an ARNI. In contrast, NT-proBNP is not subject to such degradation and is therefore considered a more reliable marker than BNP in patients taking ARNI therapy.

Key learning point: Initiation of sacubitril-valsartan often leads to increases in circulating levels of brain natriuretic peptide, but not N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide.

E) INCORRECT:

Decompensated heart failure is often associated with elevated BNP levels, but this patient lacks jugular venous distention or other physical examination findings (e.g., significant lower-extremity edema, abdominal distention, pulmonary rales) or symptoms (e.g., orthopnea, dyspnea on exertion) that are consistent with that diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and asthma comes to the office because of a 2-month history of intermittent dry, hacking cough. He does not have fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He does not smoke cigarettes. Current medications include simvastatin, metformin, albuterol, and ramipril. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action?

choices.text: Start dextromethorphan and increase frequency of albuterol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dextromethorphan is an NMDA glutamate receptor antagonist used as an over-the-counter cough suppressant and albuterol is a beta-2 agonist used in the treatment of asthma. While dextromethorphan might temporarily mitigate this patient's cough, it would not address the root cause of it. Additionally, there is no other evidence that this patient's cough is associated with an asthma exacerbation (such as dyspnea, wheezing, or chest tightness); increasing albuterol is therefore unlikely to resolve this problem.

B) INCORRECT:

Both simvastatin and atorvastatin are statins, which are indicated to treat hyperlipidemia and act by decreasing LDL levels. Classic side effects of statins include myopathy and rhabdomyolysis but not cough. Therefore, changing the patient's medication from simvastatin to atorvastatin would be unlikely to resolve his cough.

C) CORRECT:

Dry cough is a characteristic side effect of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). ACE inhibitors decrease blood pressure by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Inhibition of ACE also causes an increase in bradykinin, which can lead to bronchoconstriction and dry cough. If cough caused by ACE inhibitors is present, discontinuation of ACE inhibitors and switching to angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) such as candesartan is recommended. Cough is a rare adverse effect of ARBs, as these agents do not influence the breakdown of kinins.

Other common adverse effects of ACE inhibitors include hypotension, hyperkalemia, a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and angioedema.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

D) INCORRECT:

Ramipril and lisinopril are both angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). A common side effect of treatment with ACE inhibitors is an intermittent, nonproductive cough, such as the one seen in this patient. Because all ACE inhibitors are known to cause this cough, switching from one agent to another within this class would be unlikely to resolve the problem.

E) INCORRECT:

Albuterol and salmeterol are both beta-2 adrenergic agonists used in the treatment of asthma. While albuterol is a short-acting agent used for acute asthma exacerbations, salmeterol is a long-acting agent used for prophylaxis of asthma attacks. Although this patient has a history of asthma, his current cough seems unrelated to it. He does not have a history or findings to suggest exacerbation of asthma (e.g., exposure to triggers, dyspnea, or tachypnea on examination). Moreover, stopping albuterol would not be appropriate if there was any suspicion of an asthma exacerbation.
questions.hint: Increased local concentrations of bradykinin and substance P are thought to be responsible for the symptom this patient is experiencing.

questions.text: Three days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old woman with resistant hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the office because of decreased urination. She denies dysuria, fevers, or chills. Blood pressure is 133/67 mm Hg. Compared to measurements from one week ago, the glomerular filtration rate is markedly decreased and plasma renin activity is elevated. A duplex ultrasound of the kidneys shows increased systolic flow velocity in both renal arteries when compared to the aorta. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's worsening renal function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the ascending loop of Henle. Although diuresis may decrease the glomerular filtration rate, it does not augment the activity of renin.

B) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone acts on the distal convoluted tubules. It does not directly reduce glomerular filtration rate or increase the activity of renin.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic that acts on the proximal portion of the distal convoluted tubules. Although diuresis may decrease the glomerular filtration rate, it does not increase the activity of renin.

D) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors like enalapril inhibit efferent arteriole constriction, which can lead to a decrease in the GFR and acute kidney injury, as seen here. Patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis are especially susceptible to this effect, as the kidneys rely on efferent arteriole constriction to maintain the GFR. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) work in a similar fashion. Therefore, both ARBs and ACEIs are relatively contraindicated in patients with bilateral renal stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a selective beta blocker that is used to treat hypertension. Beta blockers do not exhibit a marked effect on glomerular filtration rate and should decrease, not increase, renin activity at normal doses.
questions.hint: This patient's duplex ultrasound shows findings consistent with renal artery stenosis, which manifests with increased flow velocity from the narrowed artery.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension comes to the office for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg on the left arm and 162/90 mm Hg on the right arm. He reports that he is adherent with his medication and exercise regimen. The provider adds a drug to his antihypertensive medication regimen. This drug increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels, and decreases serum aldosterone levels, without affecting bradykinin levels. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Candesartan, which is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), would inhibit the downstream effects of the angiotensin II receptor type 1 (AT1 receptor) such as vasoconstriction and aldosterone release. This leads to lower levels of aldosterone and decreased reabsorption of Na+ and water. To compensate for decreased Na+ and water reabsorption, the juxtaglomerular apparatus will release more renin, which will subsequently increase the levels of both angiotensin I and angiotensin II. Meanwhile, bradykinin levels are not affected, as ARBs have no effect on ACE, which metabolizes bradykinin.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

B) INCORRECT:

Aliskiren, which is a direct renin inhibitor, has no effect on bradykinin levels because it does not affect the activity of ACE. It would also cause a compensatory increase in renin secretion by the juxtaglomerular cells. However, renin inhibition by aliskiren would decrease the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I. Consequently, the levels of angiotensin I and angiotensin II would be decreased rather than increased. Aldosterone levels would be decreased due to decreased angiotensin II levels.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

C) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that lowers blood pressure by various mechanisms, including vasodilation. Vasodilation would stimulate the renin-angiotensin system and increase serum levels of renin, angiotensin I, angiotensin II, and aldosterone, without affecting bradykinin levels. The drug that was administered to this patient decreases aldosterone levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril, which is an ACE inhibitor, blocks the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. It consequently causes a decrease in angiotensin II and aldosterone levels and a compensatory increase in renin and angiotensin I levels increase. As bradykinin undergoes degradation by ACE, lisinopril leads to increased bradykinin levels.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

E) INCORRECT:

Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by inhibiting the sodium channel in the cortical collecting tubule. It does not affect the activity of ACE and therefore has no effect on bradykinin levels. However, natriuresis caused by triamterene would stimulate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Consequently, the levels of renin, angiotensin I, angiotensin II, and aldosterone would all be expected to increase rather than decrease.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.
questions.hint: The drug that was most likely prescribed for this patient is used as an alternative to ACE inhibitors in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors due to bradykinin-induced side effects such as a dry cough.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Eight months ago, she underwent an emergency cardiac catheterization with stenting for myocardial infarction. At the time of discharge, her heart configuration was normal, end-diastolic volume was 300 mL, and ejection fraction was 51%. For the past 6 weeks, she has noticed increasing shortness of breath on exertion. She has hypertension and coronary artery disease, but admits to rarely taking her medication. Echocardiography shows left ventricular thinning and dilation, an increase in end-diastolic volume, and a decrease in ejection fraction. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's worsening of ventricular function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is usually added to baseline treatment with furosemide in patients with HF who do not achieve sufficient diuresis with loop diuretics alone. Thiazides are used for symptom relief, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

B) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as enalapril have been found to decrease cardiac remodeling by slowing down the rate of left ventricular thinning and dilation after acute MI. This effect is achieved by decreasing preload and afterload due to blockage of angiotensin II. This patient's presentation with dyspnea on exertion, left ventricular dilation on echocardiogram, and a decrease in ejection fraction is consistent with mild to moderate HF.

Indications for ACE inhibitors (and angiotensin II receptor antagonists) in the secondary prevention of MI include heart failure, left ventricular ejection fraction < 40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, stable chronic kidney disease, and ST-segment elevation MI (especially with anterior location). Beta blockers have also been shown to have anti-remodeling effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Although inotropic agents such as digoxin improve hemodynamic function in patients with HF, it is mainly used for symptom improvement, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

D) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine has been found to worsen symptoms and hemodynamic status in patients with HF and reduced ejection fraction. Although recent studies have shown attenuated cardiac remodeling when nifedipine is used, there are alternative drugs that have been established as first-line therapy for cardiac remodeling prevention.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) such as diltiazem have not been found to improve mortality and/or remodeling in patients with HF secondary to myocardial infarction. CCBs are mainly used for symptomatic treatment.
questions.hint: This woman did not adhere to her medication regimen after a myocardial infarction (MI). She now presents with dyspnea on exertion, reduced ejection fraction, and left ventricular thinning and dilation, which is consistent with heart failure (HF), most likely due to unhindered cardiac remodeling.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man presents with sudden swelling of his lips and tongue. He has hypertension controlled with an ACE inhibitor for two weeks. He denies any new foods, medications, or insect exposures. He speaks with some difficulty but is not in acute distress. Physical examination shows nonpitting edema of the lips and tongue without other findings. Laboratory tests, including CBC, are unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Switch to a different ACE inhibitor

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema results from the accumulation of bradykinin due to inhibited degradation, leading to increased vascular permeability, especially in the oropharyngeal region. The patient's nonpitting edema of the lips and tongue, without other allergic or laboratory abnormalities, aligns with this mechanism. This side effect can occur after weeks of therapy and is independent of immunoglobulin E pathways. Immediate discontinuation of the ACE inhibitor is crucial to prevent further bradykinin accumulation and reduce the risk of airway compromise.

Key learning point: Angioedema is a known side effect of ACE inhibitors like Ramipril and can occur at any time during treatment, often within the first few weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum tryptase is useful in evaluating mast cell–mediated reactions like anaphylaxis, where elevated levels indicate degranulation. This patient lacks systemic features of mast cell degranulation, such as urticaria or hypotension. The nonpitting edema and ACE inhibitor use suggest a bradykinin-mediated mechanism, where tryptase levels remain normal, rendering the test unhelpful.

C) INCORRECT:

All ACE inhibitors can cause bradykinin accumulation, leading to angioedema. The nonpitting edema of the lips and tongue in this patient suggests this mechanism. Switching to another ACE inhibitor does not alter the underlying pathophysiology and does not reduce the risk of recurrent angioedema.

D) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is effective in IgE-mediated anaphylaxis, reversing vasodilation, bronchospasm, and hypotension. However, ACE inhibitor–induced angioedema is mediated by bradykinin, not histamine, and lacks systemic features like hives or hypotension. The absence of new triggers and the patient's medication history suggest a bradykinin-mediated process, making epinephrine ineffective in this context.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man returns for a follow-up visit 8 weeks after discharge for an ST-elevation myocardial infarction. He experiences only mild exertional dyspnea. His current medications include aspirin, a beta-blocker, a high-intensity statin, and an ACE inhibitor. Physical examination is normal, and vital signs are stable (see report).
Echocardiography: Left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding his ACE inhibitor therapy?

choices.text: Stop the ACE inhibitor once he has been symptom-free for 6 months
Stop the ACE inhibitor after 1 year if stable
Stop the ACE inhibitor if ejection fraction improves above 40%

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stopping ACE inhibitors based on symptom-free status disregards the persistent myocardial dysfunction indicated by a reduced ejection fraction. ACE inhibitors reduce afterload and prevent adverse remodeling, contributing to long-term mortality reduction and heart failure prevention, beyond symptomatic relief.

B) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing ACE inhibitors after one year, despite clinical stability, ignores the ongoing benefits in patients with reduced ejection fraction post-MI. ACE inhibitors prevent adverse cardiac remodeling and further ventricular function deterioration, reducing mortality and morbidity in systolic dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing ACE inhibitors based on improved ejection fraction overlooks their benefits beyond ejection fraction improvement. They reduce mortality and rehospitalization in post-MI patients with left ventricular dysfunction by mitigating adverse remodeling and modulating neurohormonal activation. The underlying myocardial scar and neurohormonal changes persist despite ejection fraction improvement.

D) CORRECT:

In post-myocardial infarction (MI) management, especially with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) ≤40%, long-term ACE inhibitor therapy is essential. ACE inhibitors modulate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, reducing afterload and preventing adverse ventricular remodeling. They improve myocardial function and reduce mortality and heart failure incidence in patients with reduced systolic function. These benefits support the indefinite continuation of ACE inhibitors as part of secondary prevention after MI.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors should be used indefinitely in patients with clinically evident heart failure or left ventricular dysfunction following myocardial infarction for secondary prevention.

questions.text: An overweight 58-year-old man with hypertension and mild diabetic nephropathy experiences a troubling cough while on an ACE inhibitor. Which medication is most appropriate next?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol, a beta-1 selective blocker, lowers blood pressure by reducing heart rate and contractility but lacks renal protection in diabetic nephropathy. It does not modulate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system to preserve glomerular filtration and can blunt hypoglycemia symptoms, making it less desirable for diabetic patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, effectively reduces blood pressure by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal tubules. However, it does not provide the renal protective benefits needed in diabetic nephropathy, nor does it address the bradykinin-mediated cough caused by ACE inhibitors.

C) CORRECT:

Irbesartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that antagonizes the binding of angiotensin II to the AT1 receptor, reducing vasoconstriction and aldosterone secretion. This action lowers blood pressure and diminishes proteinuria, slowing the progression of diabetic nephropathy by mitigating intraglomerular hypertension. In patients who develop a cough with ACE inhibitors due to increased bradykinin levels, transitioning to an ARB like irbesartan provides similar renoprotective and antihypertensive benefits without causing cough.

Key learning point: Irbesartan is an angiotensin receptor II blocker (ARB) used to manage hypertension and reduce cardiovascular risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine, a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, lowers blood pressure through vasodilation. However, it lacks renoprotective properties, such as reducing proteinuria or slowing diabetic nephropathy progression, which are crucial in this patient with mild diabetic nephropathy. Amlodipine does not address the underlying renal concerns or the cough associated with ACE inhibitors.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents for a routine follow-up. He has a 12-year history of type 2 diabetes and takes metformin only. Blood pressures over the last six months have been around 140–150/90–95 mm Hg. He denies allergies (see lab results).

Blood pressure
148/92 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
141 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Estimated GFR
52 mL/min/1.73 m²
≥ 60 mL/min/1.73 m²


Urine




 Protein
2+
Absent



Which medication is most likely to slow progression of his kidney disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol, a nonselective beta-blocker with alpha-1-blocking properties, lowers blood pressure and manages heart failure. However, it does not specifically modulate glomerular hemodynamics or target the renin-angiotensin system, which are essential for slowing diabetic nephropathy progression.

B) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine, a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, lowers blood pressure through peripheral vasodilation. However, it does not specifically target the renin-angiotensin system, which is crucial in reducing proteinuria and intraglomerular hypertension in diabetic nephropathy. While effective for hypertension, it lacks the renoprotective effects needed in this context.

C) INCORRECT:

Chlorthalidone, a thiazide-like diuretic, lowers blood pressure by promoting natriuresis. However, it does not address the intraglomerular hypertension mediated by the renin-angiotensin system, which is critical in reducing proteinuria and slowing kidney damage in diabetic nephropathy.

D) CORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy involves glomerular hyperfiltration and increased intraglomerular pressure, leading to proteinuria and declining kidney function. Enalapril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, reduces angiotensin II levels, decreasing efferent arteriolar constriction and intraglomerular pressure. This action reduces proteinuria and slows glomerular damage. In patients with diabetes and early chronic kidney disease, ACE inhibitors provide renal protection by addressing the pathological mechanisms of kidney damage, in addition to controlling blood pressure.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors like Enalapril are effective in reducing proteinuria and slowing the progression of chronic kidney disease by providing renal protection and controlling blood pressure.

questions.text: You are seeing a 74-year-old woman in your clinic for follow-up. Eight months ago, she underwent emergency cardiac catheterization with stenting for a myocardial infarction. At discharge, her heart configuration was normal, end-diastolic volume was 300 mL, and ejection fraction was 51%. Over the past 6 weeks, she has experienced increasing shortness of breath on exertion. She has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease, but reports rarely taking her medication. Echocardiography now shows left ventricular thinning and dilation, increased end-diastolic volume, and decreased ejection fraction. Which one of the following is most likely to have prevented her worsening ventricular function?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine has been found to worsen symptoms and hemodynamic status in patients with HF and reduced ejection fraction. Although recent studies have shown attenuated cardiac remodeling when nifedipine is used, there are alternative drugs that have been established as first-line therapy for cardiac remodeling prevention.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is usually added to baseline treatment with furosemide in patients with HF who do not achieve sufficient diuresis with loop diuretics alone. Thiazides are used for symptom relief, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) such as diltiazem have not been found to improve mortality and/or remodeling in patients with HF secondary to myocardial infarction. CCBs are mainly used for symptomatic treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Although inotropic agents such as digoxin improve hemodynamic function in patients with HF, it is mainly used for symptom improvement, not for prevention of cardiac remodeling.

E) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as enalapril have been found to decrease cardiac remodeling by slowing down the rate of left ventricular thinning and dilation after acute MI. This effect is achieved by decreasing preload and afterload due to blockage of angiotensin II. This patient's presentation with dyspnea on exertion, left ventricular dilation on echocardiogram, and a decrease in ejection fraction is consistent with mild to moderate HF.

Indications for ACE inhibitors (and angiotensin II receptor antagonists) in the secondary prevention of MI include heart failure, left ventricular ejection fraction < 40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, stable chronic kidney disease, and ST-segment elevation MI (especially with anterior location). Beta blockers have also been shown to have anti-remodeling effects.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors reduce cardiac remodeling and progression to heart failure after myocardial infarction by inhibiting angiotensin II, thereby decreasing preload and afterload.
questions.hint: This woman did not adhere to her medication regimen after a myocardial infarction (MI). She now presents with dyspnea on exertion, reduced ejection fraction, and left ventricular thinning and dilation, which is consistent with heart failure (HF), most likely due to unhindered cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and asthma comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of intermittent dry, hacking cough. He does not have fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He does not smoke. His current medications are simvastatin, metformin, albuterol, and ramipril. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial action?

choices.text: Start dextromethorphan and increase frequency of albuterol.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Both simvastatin and atorvastatin are statins, which are indicated to treat hyperlipidemia and act by decreasing LDL levels. Classic side effects of statins include myopathy and rhabdomyolysis; cough is extremely rare, with only a few case reports of statin-induced cough.

B) INCORRECT:

Ramipril and lisinopril are angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. A common adverse effect of ACE inhibitors is an intermittent, nonproductive cough, as in this patient. All ACE inhibitors can cause cough; while some (e.g., perindopril, enalapril) have slightly lower risk, lisinopril is only marginally less likely than ramipril to cause it. Switching between ACE inhibitors rarely resolves the problem.

C) INCORRECT:

Albuterol and salmeterol are both beta-2 adrenergic agonists used in the treatment of asthma. While albuterol is a short-acting agent used for acute asthma exacerbations, salmeterol is a long-acting agent used for prophylaxis of asthma attacks. Although this patient has a history of asthma, his current cough seems unrelated to it. He does not have a history or findings to suggest exacerbation of asthma (e.g., exposure to triggers, dyspnea, or tachypnea on examination). Moreover, stopping albuterol would not be appropriate if there was any suspicion of an asthma exacerbation.

D) CORRECT:

Dry cough is a characteristic side effect of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors). ACE inhibitors decrease blood pressure by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Inhibition of ACE also causes an increase in bradykinin, which can lead to bronchoconstriction and dry cough. The risk of ACE inhibitor-induced cough is not dose-dependent, and reducing the dose rarely relieves symptoms. If a cough caused by ACE inhibitors is present, discontinuation of ACE inhibitors and switching to angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) such as candesartan is recommended. Cough is a rare adverse effect of ARBs, as these agents do not influence the breakdown of kinins.

Other common adverse effects of ACE inhibitors include hypotension, hyperkalemia, a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, and angioedema.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitor-induced dry cough should be managed by discontinuing the ACE inhibitor and switching to an angiotensin receptor blocker.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

E) INCORRECT:

Dextromethorphan is an NMDA glutamate receptor antagonist used as an over-the-counter cough suppressant and albuterol is a beta-2 agonist used in the treatment of asthma. While dextromethorphan might temporarily mitigate this patient's cough, it would not address the root cause of it. Additionally, there is no other evidence that this patient's cough is associated with an asthma exacerbation (such as dyspnea, wheezing, or chest tightness); increasing albuterol is therefore unlikely to resolve this problem.
questions.hint: Increased local concentrations of bradykinin and substance P are thought to be responsible for the symptom this patient is experiencing.

questions.text: Three days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old woman with resistant hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to your clinic because of decreased urination. She does not report dysuria, fever, or chills. Her blood pressure is 133/67 mm Hg. Compared to one week ago, her glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is markedly decreased, and plasma renin activity is elevated. Duplex ultrasound of the kidneys shows increased systolic flow velocity in both renal arteries compared to the aorta. Which one of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her worsening renal function?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors like enalapril inhibit efferent arteriole constriction, which can lead to a decrease in the GFR and acute kidney injury, as seen here. Patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis are especially susceptible to this effect, as the kidneys rely on efferent arteriole constriction to maintain the GFR. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) work similarly. Therefore, both ARBs and ACEIs are used with caution in patients with bilateral renal stenosis.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors and ARBs can cause acute kidney injury in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a selective beta blocker that is used to treat hypertension. Beta blockers do not exhibit a marked effect on glomerular filtration rate and should decrease, not increase, renin activity at normal doses.

C) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist, which acts on the distal convoluted tubules and reduces sodium and water retention while sparing potassium. It does not cause an abrupt, severe decrease in GFR in patients with renovascular disease unless there is significant pre-existing volume depletion.

D) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic, which acts on the ascending loop of Henle. It does not cause an abrupt, severe decrease in GFR in patients with renovascular disease unless there is significant pre-existing volume depletion.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic, which acts on the proximal portion of the distal convoluted tubules and lowers blood pressure primarily through natriuresis. It does not cause an abrupt, severe decrease in GFR in patients with renovascular disease unless there is significant pre-existing volume depletion.
questions.hint: This patient's duplex ultrasound shows findings consistent with bilateral renal artery stenosis, which manifests with increased flow velocity from the narrowed artery.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension comes to your clinic for follow-up. His blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg in the left arm and 162/90 mm Hg in the right arm. He reports adherence to his medication and exercise regimen. You add a drug to his antihypertensive regimen. This drug increases serum renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels, and decreases serum aldosterone levels, without affecting bradykinin levels. Which one of the following drugs was most likely added to his medication regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that lowers blood pressure by various mechanisms, including vasodilation. While vasodilation can activate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), studies have shown that verapamil does not significantly alter renin or angiotensin II levels. Moreover, a change in bradykinin levels would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Captopril, which is an ACE inhibitor, blocks the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. It consequently causes a decrease in angiotensin II and aldosterone levels and a compensatory increase in renin and angiotensin I levels. As bradykinin undergoes degradation by ACE, captopril leads to increased bradykinin levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor, decreasing the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I. It does cause a compensatory increase in renin secretion by the juxtaglomerular cells, but the levels of angiotensin I and angiotensin II would decrease rather than increase. Aldosterone levels may also decrease due to decreased angiotensin II levels. Moreover, aliskiren increases bradykinin levels by upregulating tissue kallikrein expression, independent of ACE activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by inhibiting the sodium channel in the cortical collecting tubule. It does not affect the activity of ACE and therefore has no effect on bradykinin levels. However, natriuresis caused by triamterene would stimulate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Consequently, the levels of renin, angiotensin I, angiotensin II, and aldosterone would all be expected to increase rather than decrease.

E) CORRECT:

Losartan, which is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), would inhibit the downstream effects of the angiotensin II receptor type 1 (AT1 receptor) such as vasoconstriction and aldosterone release. This leads to lower levels of aldosterone and decreased reabsorption of Na+ and water. To compensate for decreased Na+ and water reabsorption, the juxtaglomerular apparatus will release more renin, which will subsequently increase the levels of both angiotensin I and angiotensin II. Meanwhile, bradykinin levels are not affected, as ARBs have no effect on ACE, which metabolizes bradykinin.

Key learning point: Angiotensin receptor blockers increase renin, angiotensin I, and angiotensin II levels, decrease aldosterone, and do not affect bradykinin because they block angiotensin II type 1 receptors without inhibiting ACE.
Image Description:

Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.

The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.
questions.hint: The drug that was most likely prescribed for this patient is used as an alternative to ACE inhibitors in patients who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors due to bradykinin-induced side effects such as a dry cough.
